awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2019 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Isabel Vogt is "Arithmetic and geometry of algebraic curves". The host institution for the fellowship is Stanford University and the sponsoring scientist is Ravi Vakil.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This award supported research into the geometry of the set of solutions to a collection of polynomial equations, as well as the arithmetic when the solutions are required to be integers or fractions (or other arithmetically interesting generalizations).  The main focus was on the case of one-dimensional solution sets (so-called algebraic curves) in a space of arbitrary dimension.  The possible such algebraic curves are classified by Brill--Noether theory, a topic that is most well-developed in the case that the curve is "general".  One of the fundamental problems studied was the interpolation problem for curves: given a random collection of points, when does there exist a curve of a fixed type passing through all of those points?

Key results of this research include (1) the first complete analogue of the classic Brill--Noether theorem for a class of "special" curves, namely curves of fixed gonality; (2) a complete solution to the interpolation problem for general curves (so-called Brill--Noether curves) -- featured by Quanta Magazine as one of the biggest breakthroughs in math in 2022; (3) classification results for the "arithmetic complexity" of a curve measuring finiteness of points of bounded degree and its relationship with the gonality; (4) data on the Galois properties of the torsion points of approximately 1.8 million curves of genus 2, which has been incorporated into the public L-functions and Modular Forms Database LMFDB.org. During the grant period the PI also organized collaborative research opportunities and summer schools and mentored undergraduate and graduate students.

The results of this research are available on arxiv.org, as well as the PI's webpage.  The PI gave numerous research talks across North America, Europe, and virtually on Zoom to further increase dissemination.

 


Last Modified: 12/07/2023
Modified by: Isabel M Vogt
